monogr.title: A true and experimentall discourse, upon the beginning, proceeding, and victorious event of this last siege of Breda : With the antiquity and annexing of it, to the house of Nassaw, and the many alterations it hath suffered by armes, and armies, within these threescore yeares. Together with the prudent plots, projects, and policies of warre: the assailants and defendants matchlesse man-hood, in managing martiall affaires: the misery and manner of souldiers living, their pinching want, and fatall accidents: strange weapons and instruments used by both parties in severall conflicts. Lastly, their concluded articles, with the circumstances and ordering of the siege and victory. Being pleasant to peruse, and profitable to observe. Written by him who was an eye witnesse of the siege. William Lithgow

div.head: The Prologue to the Ingenious READER.
div.p:
THou mayst admire to see my flying Quill come unto such a low flight, as the Belgian Provinces:His booke of nineteene years travailes, performed by 3. several voyages. which formerly slighted (in the late and large Discourse of my long and fastidious Travailes) this Westerne World: but made a step from Paris to Rome: Nay, scarce of Rome it selfe, would my pen peruse any paines, till my face sighted Greece, and Easterne Europe. Whence there my feete footing pedestrially many Regions in Asia, and thence consequently Voyaging in Affrica, by two severall turnes and Returnes. It is a wonder (I say) to behold my Remote Labours, fall now upon Breda in Brabant, our neighbour soile, divided from us only (as it were) by a Channel of the Sea. And yet reason fortifieth my intention, since now inability of body, restraineth me from any further lanching abroad, and my preteriat daies of long worne time, being stricken in age, retroverteth
the ancient Proverbe backwards upon my selfe: To wit, That young men have wide eies abroad, and old men narrow eies at home: VVhich now I begin reciprocally to countercambiat, being of both sayings participant. But vnderstand me better,A comparison betweene Gyants and Dwarfes, re
• orded by Pliny & Virgil. were not Conopas and Molon two little Dwarfes, as much Renowned in Pliny for their smalnesse, as those two huge and monsterous Gyants Cyclops and Enceladus rest famous in Virgil for their bignes. And why may not a Mountaine produce a Mole-hill: for although, perhaps, this present matter seeme to thee as a Flie sitting upon an Elephants back, in comparison of those my rarer Relations formerly exhibited to the wide desirous World: yet now the time, the sight, the place, the subject, and the accidents about Breda,
• he sight of • reda incited • he Author to • erforme this • orke. command me, and have commanded me to leave a stampe of their Protractures to this present Age, and succeeding times. Which thou shalt not peruse like to flashing Currants, lying surmises, blind-folded Gazetoes, feined by Domesticke imaginations, or frivolous reports of flying doubts. No, no, but receive and read this Worke from my owne occular experience, whereof I was a daily Testator. And it also besides, being grounded upon the soundest judgements of the best Officers there, but indeed more narrowly searched by me from the common souldiers,E • perience excelleth farre all flying reports. who daily and nightly were incident unto the Tragicall accidents of the subject it selfe, from whom as from a fountaine, I have drawne the Christall truth of this Relation, so much as concerned their passive
proofe and Knowledge, the rest and best relyeth upon my selfe.

Neverthelesse (Gentle Reader) if this familiar stile seeme not to thee so accurate and Elegant, as I have done heretofore in other Workes, impute the fault thereof to a disordered Leaguer, my miserable lying on cold straw, in straw huts, and unshifted apparrell, to the clangor of Armour, the ratling of Pikes, the hurling of shouldring Muskets,The disturbant impediments of an Army, to a pen-man▪ the clamour of tongues, the sounding of Trumpets, and the noise of Drums: where, when, and whilst I was in writing this experimentall Discourse, distempered my quietnes. Yet howsoever that turbulent time, crossed my Pilgrimagious paines, I have made it plaine to the ignorant, and intelligible to the Prudent, and withall to satisfie the apprehension of any curious conception. And so I rest, leaving thee, as I leave my selfe,

closer.signed: To be thine, as thou art mine, William Lithgow.
